events.place: Formation of the British East India Company
events.description: In the year 1600, the British East India Company was founded. It played a significant role in British colonization and trade in India.
The Battle of Plassey in 1757 was a pivotal moment in Indian history. It marked the beginning of British control over India and the decline of the Mughal Empire.
The Battle of Buxar in 1764 was a significant conflict that further solidified British control over India. It led to the Treaty of Allahabad and the expansion of British influence.
The Indian Rebellion of 1857, also known as the Indian Mutiny or the First War of Independence, was a widespread uprising against British rule in India.
In 1858, following the Indian Rebellion, the British formally ended the Mughal Empire, marking the end of a centuries-old dynasty.
The Jallianwala Bagh Massacre was a tragic event in 1919 when British troops opened fire on a peaceful gathering in Amritsar, leading to many casualties.
The Quit India Movement was a significant civil disobedience campaign launched by Mahatma Gandhi in 1942, demanding an end to British rule in India.
India gained independence from British rule in 1947, leading to the establishment of the Republic of India.
In 1947, the Indian subcontinent was partitioned into two independent nations, India and Pakistan, leading to significant demographic shifts and upheaval.
